verses.text: Around that time, King Herod began to harass certain members of the church.
verses.comment: This Herod is Agrippa I, distinct from the Herod of Jesus' trial. The term 'church' (Greek ekklesia) emphasizes the gathered body of believers. Note the continuity with Acts 8's persecution.

verses.text: He killed James, the brother of John, with the sword.
verses.comment: James is the first apostle to be martyred, fulfilling Jesus' prophecy about sharing his cup of suffering (Matt. 20:23).

verses.text: When Herod saw that this pleased the Jews, he also arrested Peter. This happened during the days of Unleavened Bread.
verses.comment: The Feast of Unleavened Bread ties the New Testament community to the Old Testament, showing continuity with God's people.

verses.text: After arresting him, Herod put Peter in prison, handing him over to four squads of soldiers to guard him, intending to bring him out to the people after Passover.
verses.comment: Herod's careful guarding shows Peter's prominence, hinting at his special role among the apostles.

verses.text: So Peter was kept in prison, but earnest prayer for him was being made to God by the church.
verses.comment: The whole community intercedes for Peter, showing the power and unity of corporate prayer.

verses.text: On the very night when Herod was about to bring him out, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with chains, and guards before the door were keeping watch over the prison.
verses.comment: Peter's composure displays trust in God, even moments before potential execution.

verses.text: Suddenly, an angel of the Lord stood beside him, and a light shone in the cell. The angel struck Peter on the side, woke him up, and said, 'Get up quickly.' The chains fell off his hands.
verses.comment: God's supernatural intervention echoes Old Testament angelic deliverances, signifying the apostles' divine mandate.

verses.text: Then the angel said to him, 'Dress yourself and put on your sandals.' And Peter did so. The angel said, 'Wrap your cloak around you and follow me.'
verses.comment: The angel's guidance parallels other moments where divine messengers prepare God's servants for mission.

verses.text: Peter went out and followed him. He did not realize that what was being done by the angel was real, but thought he was seeing a vision.
verses.comment: Peter's initial confusion highlights the mysterious nature of God's interventions.

verses.text: When they had passed the first and second guard, they came to the iron gate leading to the city. It opened for them by itself, and they went out and walked along one street. Immediately the angel left him.
verses.comment: The opening of the gate by itself recalls God parting the Red Sea, underscoring divine deliverance.

verses.text: When Peter came to himself, he said, 'Now I know for certain that the Lord has sent his angel and rescued me from Herod’s hand and from all that the Jewish people were expecting.'
verses.comment: Acknowledgement of God as rescuer recalls Daniel's deliverance (Dan. 6:22) and Peter's earlier escape (Acts 5:19).

verses.text: When he realized this, he went to the house of Mary, the mother of John who was called Mark, where many were gathered and praying.
verses.comment: The early believers continued meeting in homes for worship and prayer, showing the strength of their communal life.

verses.text: When he knocked at the door of the gateway, a servant girl named Rhoda came to answer.
verses.comment: Peter returns to his community, relying on its hospitality and support.

verses.text: Recognizing Peter’s voice, she was so overjoyed that she left the gate unopened and ran in, declaring that Peter was standing outside.
verses.comment: Rhoda’s joy reflects the hope in answered prayer.

verses.text: They said to her, 'You are out of your mind.' But she kept insisting that it was so, and they kept saying, 'It must be his angel.'
verses.comment: The mention of 'his angel' hints at spiritual realities accompanying believers (see Matt. 18:10).

verses.text: But Peter kept knocking, and when they opened the door, they saw him and were astonished.
verses.comment: God’s answers to prayer often exceed human expectations.

verses.text: He motioned with his hand for them to be silent, and described how the Lord had brought him out of the prison. He said, 'Tell these things to James and to the brothers.' Then he left and went to another place.
verses.comment: Peter refers to 'James and the brothers', indicating leadership continuity in the church even as Peter departs.

verses.text: When morning came, there was no small commotion among the soldiers as to what had become of Peter.
verses.comment: The miraculous nature of Peter's escape is evident to all.

verses.text: Herod searched for Peter and could not find him. After examining the guards, he ordered them to be put to death. Then he went down from Judea to Caesarea and stayed there.
verses.comment: Roman law held guards responsible for escaped prisoners; here punishment is severe, reflecting the authorities’ frustration.

verses.text: Now Herod was angry with the people of Tyre and Sidon. They came to him together. After persuading Blastus, the king’s chamberlain, they asked for peace, because their country depended on the king’s country for food.
verses.comment: Political dynamics and dependence for resources shape ancient diplomacy.

verses.text: On an appointed day, Herod put on his royal robes, sat on the throne, and delivered an address to them.
verses.comment: Herod’s display of power is reminiscent of other rulers in biblical history.

verses.text: The people shouted, 'This is the voice of a god, not of a man!'
verses.comment: Herod accepts divine honors, an act of pride condemned throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Immediately, an angel of the Lord struck him, because he did not give glory to God, and he was eaten by worms and died.
verses.comment: Herod’s fate mirrors that of other prideful rulers, punished for ignoring God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: But the word of God continued to grow and multiply.
verses.comment: Despite opposition, God’s word flourishes, fulfilling Isaiah 55:11.

verses.text: And Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem after completing their mission, taking with them John who was called Mark.
verses.comment: The inclusion of Mark here links the apostolic ministry with well-organized transmission and trustworthy witnesses, preparing for greater missionary expansion.
